comments.commentBody: I agree with Highlight.  I cancelled my membership with AARP when they backed the Part D program.  Then, they talked me back into joining.  This may be the straw that broke this old cambels back. I just started taking my social security this year (70 years old).  My wife (she started hers at 62) receive 3500 per month from social security.  Thats far more than average, I started paying into the system at 15 years old and the only time I did not pay into was during my college years. In fact, I continue to work part time and still pay into social security without any potential added monthly benefits.  Social security is about a 1/3rd of my income without working.  I don't need the money but I am concerned about people that are not as lucky as I have been during my life time.  I stilldo not understand why a couple making 42 thousand a year only has to pay taxes on 85 per cent of soscial security.  When you make that much...tax all of it.
HERO!!! Thank you to all those who fight and protects america...

Military commanders are not authorized to start wars. Not even the Commander in Chief, once he dons his military role. They are obliged by the constitution to fight the wars that congress declares, and on orders from the civilian leaders once that declaration has been made. The modern world makes some applications of those obligations too difficult to do, and so congress ceded some of its authority for the president to act in our self defense against imminent threats, or actual hostilities against the nation, with the strict provision that congress must approve those hostile actions within 60 days.

There is no language in either the constitution, nor in the War Powers Act that differentiates between "full blown" and other hostilities. The argument that such a difference exists or is implied in either document is just plain false! Barack Obama is clearly operating outside the legal obligations of his office, and has been for months. Now, will congress actually do something about it? Or pass because it might require them to take a stand on something they seem to like, despite the American people's opposition? So far, congress has chosen the easy road, as usual, of kicking the can down the road, hoping circumstances will break their way so they don't have to do anything other than talk about it. After which we can expect them all to make claims of how they were so against it all.

Cuts to SS........Let's see $850/ a month. Less gas, food, taxes on house, local taxes, etc., not much left over. I dropped out of AARP a long time ago......just shaking my head and wondering how to deal with next winter.
Was just going to join. Now I'm not going to join. Hope you're reading this, AARP!

I am NOT renewing my membership in AARP and I hope that millions of other members do the same and let the turncoats in Washington know.  It appears that everybody has sold out and the progressives are so weak, it's unbelievable.

8. Debbie:
Your comments about AARP were very enlightening. You've certainly given me something to think about regarding my future support of them. Thank you.

I think this is great news. As a veteran stay-at-home father, I am familiar with much of the "mother lode," I suppose, so I often benefit from reading this blog and the comments. But hearing more about how other fathers are bearing their parenting load will be helpful as well.

I think a name change might be a good thing. Some of these comments however seem like huge over reactions. The blog is great. Keep up the good work. (I am excited to hear that there will be more about pregnancy and infants since that's where I am in the process of parenthood)

The Gulf Coast still suffers from the last off shore oil drilling disaster.  Nuclear power is not safe, inexpensive or "green." I'm eager to see how Germany enacts its new energy policy.  I would rather trust the sun, the wind, conservation, American creativity and ingenuity.

I do like this idea, Lisa.  And while the mainstream media is behind the curve in recognizing all the different roles dads (sorry Bill--male parents) play in the parenting equation, I don't think men will hold grudges because of that.  I love the DIY ethos and quirky experimentalism of the blogosphere, but there's also a lot of value in having "real" journalists with budgets and access and time to do research writing about the issues that parent-bloggers of all persuasions try to hammer out while their kids are napping.

I love the idea of meatless Monday and feel no guilt about having it at home. That said, I used to hike in the Rockies and at least twice, came out of the mountains after several days of great exertion and lots of freeze dried meals. I was ravenous. Yes, on those days, I did order a big steak which hit the spot.

I know with practice, I could hike without needing meat at the end, but I think in the meantime, it would feel almost desperate!

Because Americans are living longer they are taking out of social security more than they paid in. Therefore; it is logical to raise the retirement age on those capable of work. The age of Medicare should not be raised because some Americans need the health benefits so they can continue working. BUT if the retirement age is raised something needs to be done about age descrimination. It doesn't help that the NYT just ran a story about should older workers be nudged out?

"I'm pretty sure Democrats didn't support the measure that began all of California's financial woes. Go back to the voter approved property tax restrictions and the requirement of a 2/3 majority to raise taxes if you want to source blame."

I don't know if Democrats supported these measures or not. I do know the voters of California supported them. Yes, pal, that's our problem here in California - not enough taxes. Please.

It may be that some changes to Social Security will have to be made to keep it strong into the future, but I was counting on AARP to counter, not cave into, the  Tea party nuts and Fox News and Wall Street Journal stooges on this issue. Great way to negotiate! AARP leaders seem to be taking lessons from President Obama.

That French restaurant owner who wasn't sure if a vegie dinner could be gourmet enough for his fancy restaurant needs to come to San Francisco and eat dinner at Millennium, the fancy gourmet vegan restaurant here.  He'll be convinced.

comments.userLocation: Gallipolis Ferry, WV, former New Yorker
comments.commentBody:
Nostalgia about overwhelms me every time i hear that song...some of my dearest friends in all the world are those with whom i lived in tucson Arizona for a few years, further down the road...it is almost incomprehensible how much the world has changed since we were young but i still wear my Navajo and Zuni turquoise every single day as the Indian grnadmothers do and i still smile at the thought of the pure and simple joy and romance of traveling America in the 60s and 70s.
Loving the memories still and still enjoying the haunting nature of a sweet song that captured it all so well.

Thanks for awakening a lovely memory of a 1998 trip with a now deceased friend.

It was a nice little town. I still have the weather forecast from the Winslow/Holbrooke area beaming into my computer every day...dreams die hard.

And if your really old, the next line was:"Watching all the girls go by".
I recall sitting in church at a mass attended by the students at St.James in Brooklyn. The priest, standing in the high pulpit, looked down on us and said accusingly, I know what the boys were thinking!
A piece of trivia to Dave C #32...David Crosby sang back-up on Browne's "Everyman"

I've been suspicious of AARP for a long time because of their silence on this issue.  If they were truly advocating for us they should be screaming their heads off that social security/medicare are NOT running out of money, they just need to be funded.  Funding never seems to be in short supply for corporate welfare or foreign military adventures does it?  Of course the government has already demonstrated that they can control SS benefit amounts in other ways, such as using phony formulas to calculate cost of living increases.  Wouldn't be too surprised if they cut everyone's benefit next year and told us the cost of living had decreased!
The Republican austerity plan for everyone except the wealthy and the well-connected are going to drive America into a double-dip recession.

Penny wise and pound foolish. As stated in the article, this not will only hurt the unemployed but also put further strain on the economy with less spending done by those unemployed.

The Arizona legislature already has gotten a taste of what it's like with less money in the system. Cracking down on undocumented workers exacerbated Arizona's economic woes when hundreds of thousands of illegal aliens left the state.

Nonetheless, that purported scourge not only provided a lot of labor, but they also bought a lot of stuff and paid a lot of sales tax.

Arizona conservative leadership not only believes in the trickle down economy, but the spiral-down economy.

Down, down, down,
with Senator Russell Pearce
The process of recall might obtain
Consequently he'll remain
Til they disinfect
the Mesa city sewers.

Isn't this a perfect example of how heartless and self-serving Republicans are? The Republican legislators have a job and are sitting pretty, and they don't care that their actions or lack of actions are forcing desperate, out-of-work individuals into foreclosure, into homeless shelters, into having to rely on food stamps.

Yikes. Dickens would have a field day with these creepy, heartless people.

I hope for once Americans are taking notice of how ideologically perverse and fanatically uncaring these repulsive adherents of the Republican party are. We all know that the government needs to cut costs and eliminate the deficit. But is it really necessary to accomplish this on the weary backs of the downtrodden and unemployed?

I guess the world will always be populated with self-serving, uncaring creeps. But why does this country have to have so many people like this?

“The real question is whether there is still a need for extended benefits. We are increasingly hearing from people that they are having trouble hiring workers who are on unemployment because they want to wait until their benefits are exhausted.” If the companies are having troubling hiring then why isn't Mr Ballesteros taking one of those jobs? If he still can't find a job I suggest he move. If he moves to Texas, the oil refineries are always hiring. If he moves to California he can get the Federal Unemployment extension. Since he is still in Arizon and still not working I suggest he is not too worried.
